key_work.title: Mechanical magic lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: Mechanical magic lantern slides created basic moving pictures. ‘Slipping slides’ used two glass slides featuring complementary images – one stationary and one that ‘slipped’ over the other to give the illusion of movement, while levers and pulley systems were also incorporated to create dynamic effects.

end.title: Mario Kart 64
end.brief_description:
Three… Two… One… GO! The signal light changes and you drop the pedal to the metal. Take on up to three friends in the split-screen VS games, or race solo in the Mario GP. Tell your friends to bring it on in the highly competitive Battle mode. Advanced features allow you to race with your “Ghost”. The driving data from your best run appears as a transparent character on the screen. No longer must you simply race against the clock — you can actually race against yourself!

  • Save your hottest Ghost data to a portable N64 Controller Pak!

  • Collect multiple power-up items!

  • Twenty different courses — 4 Cups with 4 courses each and 4 special Battle mode courses!

  • Everyone’s favorite characters are back and gorgeously rendered, including two new additions, Donkey Kong and Wario!

constellations_other.name: Lois Weber and the split-screen
constellations_other.description: Lois Weber was the third filmmaker to use split screens to show simultaneous action, helping establish it as part of cinematic language, particularly its use in thrillers. It's since been taken to extremes by auteurs and videogames.

links.description: The hallucinatory visuals of Catacombs of Solaris are reminiscent of Rainbow Road, the final track in Mario Kart 64, with its vibrant luminous blocks of rainbow colours placed against a black background to add intensity to the rapidly moving gameplay.

links.description: Magic lantern projection introduced the wonder of light and illusion. Colourful slides called chromatropes revolved to create kaleidoscopic effects. Kaleidoscopic movement and colour continue to fascinate and are used in the mesmerising title sequence of Queen Sugar.

start.brief_description: English painter J.M.W. Turner (1775–1851) has been called the ‘painter of light’. He developed new artistic techniques to capture natural phenomena, evoking the intensity and transience of light in works that are simultaneously intuitive and scientific.

links.description: Light and Colour (Goethe’s Theory) is exemplary of Turner’s innovative painting techniques, which drew on colour theory to capture the atmospheric effects of light. Magic lanterns similarly created immersive visual sensations through revolving kaleidoscopic slides known as chromotropes.
